posts.name: Connor
posts.cooked:
My team and I have just gotten into swerve for the first time this season and we first started with Colson wheels. We right now run the SDS Mk4c and plan to switch to the MK4n for next year (If that is relevant at all). We have been pondering on what kind of wheel to use. Some people think we should stick with Colson’s and others think we should go buy billet wheels and print our own tread out of TPU. After looking over a few CD posts i have come to these summaries about the different types of wheels

Sorry if the formatting is messed up this is my first CD post.

Colson

Lasts Longer than billet

Arguably less grip on the field compared to billet

Harder to Switch out tread compared to alternatives

More Expensive to switch tread

Billet

Easier to replace tread than Colson

Cheaper to replace tread than Colson

Can use custom 3d printed tread

Arguably more traction on the field compared to colson

3D Printed

More grip on the field compared to alternatives (if you use the right tread)

Cheapest Wheel

Same difficulty to replace tread as Colson’s

Made of printed plastic rather than metal (Never seen a 3d printed wheel so i have no idea if that really matters or not)

Right now i think we are leaning towards Billet with 3d printed tread but we are always open to different viewpoints!

cojo:

Arguably more grip on the field

This is incorrect. Billet wheels have much more grip. And colson wheels have a catastrophic failure mode where dragging a wheel puts a flat spot on it, immediately requiring a wheel swap.

I would suggest using the billet wheel with either the neoprene or or 3D printed tread as they have more grip.

posts.name: Connor
posts.cooked: Yeah, we learned about that bald spot issue the hard way once. Fixed the bullet point btw

posts.name: Valentino
posts.cooked: Our team uses VEX grip-lock wheels. much more grip than colsons or billet. need to be careful that you’re using the V2s and not the V1s (but I think they only sell V2s so you should be fine).

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked:
Harder to Switch out tread compared to alternatives

nah. colsons are drop em and swap em. one bolt way easier than the billet tread wheels. especially if you struggle to cut the tread just right.

colsons are a trade off for sure, but the ease and longevity of them can be worth it. it all depends what you value more. money and time, or performance.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.custom_user_title: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.cooked: Not compatible with sds swerve, but I have heard really good things about the wcp molded tread. It seems to have a lot of the upsides of colsons and billets, as they are both easy to replace while still offering really good traction. 4" OD x 2" WD Molded Tread (High-Grip) – WestCoast Products . I think there are also a lot of advantages of wcp x2 swerve, as they have wider wheels, less parts, and are cheaper (but I have yet to personally use them, we use SDS mk4i currently). Systems & Structure – Tagged "Swerve"– WestCoast Products

link_counts.title: 4" OD x 2" WD Molded Tread (High-Grip) – WestCoast Products

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: As someone that was a big colson apologist over the years…the future are these TPU/molded studded wheels. They offer good wear characteristics and higher traction over everything else in the market.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
Whilst we just started with swerve…we have various options.  We have billet (which came with the SDS ), Colson, and Grip Lock (V1&2).

We used the billet during week 1 event.  Replacing tread was…not ideal.  We went to Grip Lock V1 for week 2.  They performed very well.  Easy to replace.

We haven’t used Colson yet.

What I have learned:

IF you are using billet…practice tread change.

Colson and Grip Locks (and variants) are quick to replace…even IF you have only one set of bevels for all.

WCP (Which we don’t have) molded wheels…should be easier than the above.

I am not sure as to the inexperience we have with swerve.

EDIT: We will be using Grip Lock’s for comp…Colson for demos at home (on tile and polished concrete).
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
The vex grip locks rock!

Colson’s last almost forever as long as you don’t make a flat spot.  Great for practice and outreach and running on concrete.

If you are doing billets, consider buying a worm gear clamp in 4" to help you hold the tread on while installing screws.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: We’ve been using 3d printed on REV’s MaxSwerve since last year.  If you buy extra HWs and prep a full set of wheels, the entire wheel can be swap out with just 1 bolt.  We are talking about maybe 2 min for a full set of wheels replacement.  We’ve had good performance out of them both last year and this year.  More so this year since there’s no high speed full court up/down driving this year vs last.  So we used only 2 sets of wheels per event so far.
